para.paratext: Formerly in Georgia, a witness was not incompetent simply because of an official connection to the case at trial. With the adoption of O.C.G.A. §§ 24-6-605 and 24-6-606, no judge or juror may testify as a witness in a trial in which he is sitting. No objection is necessary to preserve the issue for appeal of a judge testifying.

Under former O.C.G.A. §§ 9-10-9 and 17-9-41, a juror could not testify about jury deliberations after jury dismissal except in criminal cases where a juror could testify as to whether prejudicial information was improperly brought to the jurors' attention, whether the jurors were improperly subjected to outside influences, or whether there was a mistake on the verdict form.[1] Now, under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-606(b), this exception is extended to civil cases as well.[2]

However, in 2017, the U.S. Supreme Court held in Pena-Rodriguez v. Colorado[3] that where a juror makes clear statements during deliberations that they are relying on racial bias to convict a criminal defendant, the Sixth Amendment requires that the no-impeachment rule give way in order to permit the trial court to consider the evidence and make sure the defendant's right to a jury trial have not been abridged. Georgia's law closely tracks federal law in this regard. In Pena-Rodriguez, a juror made statements displaying anti-Hispanic bias towards the defendant and his alibi witness based on their country of origin. The Court reasoned that the no-impeachment rule requires an exception where a juror's racial bias or animus is a significant factor in his or her finding of guilt. The Supreme Court held that trial courts must, in the case of racial bias, examine the statements made in light of the fairness and impartiality of the jury's deliberations and resulting verdict. Thus, when jurors disclose racial bias, the law must not wholly disregard its occurrence, but rather, the court must exercise its discretion and determine whether the defendant received a fair trial.

See Lloyd v. State, 339 Ga. App. 1, 792 S.E.2d 445 (2016) (juror's communication with a police officer about the law of the case being decided was harmful and prejudicial to the defendant's right to a fair trial).

In Washington v. State, 333 Ga. App. 236, 244, 775 S.E.2d 719 (2015), the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's refusal to consider affidavits from jurors “as to whether there was a mistake in entering the verdict onto the verdict form.” In Muthu v. State, 337 Ga. App. 97, 786 S.E.2d 696 (2016), the Court of Appeals held that it was proper to exclude testimony from a juror that only contained information regarding the jury's deliberation pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-6-606(b). In Beck v. State, 305 Ga. 383, 825 S.E.2d 184 (2019), the Georgia Supreme Court vacated and remanded to the trial court for deliberation on whether or not evidence obtained and argued by jurors when determining guilt was prejudicial under the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 24-6-606(b).
Pena-Rodriguez v. Colorado, 137 S. Ct. 855, 197 L. Ed. 2d 107, 102 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1084 (2017).
